intro: Dianthoveus, commonly known as the firecracker flower, is a striking member of the Caryophyllaceae family. It is native to the mountainous regions of South America, where it thrives in well-drained soils and full sun. The plant is characterized by its vibrant red, pink, or white flowers that resemble tiny fireworks, hence its common name. Dianthoveus typically grows to a height of 30–60 centimeters, with slender stems and lance-shaped leaves. It is often cultivated for its ornamental value in gardens and floral arrangements.
